componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Mead Johnson Nutrition Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Shannon, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the conference call over to Kathy MacDonald, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed, Kathy.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shannon, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Mead Johnson's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Conference Call. With me today are Kasper Jakobsen, our Chief Executive Officer; and Pete Leemputte, our Chief Financial Officer. As we start, let
componenttext:
Thank you, Shannon, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to Mead Johnson's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Conference Call. With me today are Kasper Jakobsen, our Chief Executive Officer; and Pete Leemputte, our Chief Financial Officer. As we start, let me remind everyone that our comments will include forward-looking statements about our future results, including statements about our financial prospects and projections, commodity cost, currency fluctuations, pricing, taxes, capital spending, depreciation, amortization, new product launches, product quality, other growth initiatives and market conditions that constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the safe harbor provision under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. A more detailed explanation of our forward-looking statements will appear in the materials posted on our website in connection with today's conference call. Keep in mind that our actual results may differ materially from expectations as of today due to various factors, including those listed in our annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and current reports on Form 8-K, in each case, as filed with or furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission and our earnings release issued this morning, all of which are available upon request or on our website at meadjohnson.com. 
Today's comments will include discussion of non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation of these measures to comparable GAAP measures appear in this morning's earnings release posted on our website. In addition, any forward-looking statements represent our estimates only as of today and should not be relied upon as representing our estimates as of any subsequent date. While we may elect to update forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimates change. 
I will now turn the call over to Kasper.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy, and good morning to all of you. Thank you for joining us this morning. In a moment, I'll first provide some highlights from our fourth quarter and full year 2014 before discussing our expectations for 2015. I'll then turn the call over t
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy, and good morning to all of you. Thank you for joining us this morning. In a moment, I'll first provide some highlights from our fourth quarter and full year 2014 before discussing our expectations for 2015. I'll then turn the call over to Pete, who will provide more details on our financial performance and our outlook. At the end of our prepared remarks, I will then provide a few summary remarks before I give you the opportunity to ask questions or request clarification. 
Let me now turn to our discussion of 2014. As you likely read in our press release issued this morning, we ended the year on a strong note. Despite accelerating headwinds from foreign exchange, we delivered earnings per share slightly above prior guidance, and we closed another year of strong revenue growth. Revenue growth in the fourth quarter of 2014 was 8% in constant dollars and 3% in reported U.S. dollars over prior year's quarter. On a non-GAAP basis, earnings per share for the quarter came in at $0.92, up from $0.82 in the same quarter of 2013. 
Throughout the year, we saw the value of our geographic diversification. Despite challenges in individual markets, including China, we delivered constant dollar revenue growth of 9% for the full year 2014. Volume contributed 4 percentage points to our growth rate, while higher pricing added 5 points. 200 basis points of growth came from pricing in the high-inflation environments of Argentina and Venezuela. We saw volume growth in each of our regions. After several years of weakness, our persistent investments in North America are paying off. And our North America/Europe segment grew volume faster than any other region last year. Latin America continued to show steady volume growth despite challenges in several markets within South America. And in Asia, we saw revenue growth decelerate as performance in mainland China adversely affected results for the broader region. I'll address this in more detail in a moment. 
We faced significant headwinds from foreign exchange throughout the year. This reduced our revenue growth by 4 percentage points when translated into U.S. dollars. As a result, reported U.S. dollar revenue growth was 5% for the full year 2014. The unfavorable trend in the currency markets accelerated in the fourth quarter, impacting all 3 reporting segments. 
Turning now to earnings. Non-GAAP earnings per share of $3.74 for the year was up 7% versus 2013. Our rate of earnings growth was well above the 5% increase we saw in reported U.S. dollar revenue. In light of gross margin headwinds from adverse foreign exchange movements, higher dairy costs and start-up costs associated with our new Singapore facility we're satisfied with the improvement in earnings. Our ability to leverage growth in revenue for even faster growth in earnings is the result of our commitment to prudent cost management and the effectiveness of our ongoing productivity programs. As an example, we continue to invest aggressively behind our brands and key innovation projects but found efficiencies through procurement efforts and optimized media strategies that allowed us to meet our revenue goals with marketing spend as a lower percentage of sales. Before I comment on the outlook for 2015, let me briefly comment on the performance within each of our reporting segments. 
Firstly, turning to our Asia segment. In the fourth quarter, our business in Asia grew 3% on a constant dollar basis. As mentioned previously, revenue growth for the region was adversely impacted by our China business. As I mentioned in our last call, we reduced trade inventory in China during the third quarter and early fourth quarter in advance of an Enfa relaunch in late October. We are monitoring consumer offtake following the launch closely, and we continue to see retailers reduce inventory across categories as they adopt a more cautious stand in light of a moderating growth in GDP. 
I should also note that our 2013 base for comparison was particularly tough due to an impact of a recall by several competitors in the second half of that year. On a full year basis, constant dollar sales in Asia were up 7%. Our China/Hong Kong business grew 5%. As I've stated in the past, we are currently under indexed in the higher growth channels in China, particularly the e-commerce and super-high premium segment that focus mostly on imported products. 
As we have discussed in China, just a brief note on the status of our China-related investigation. Our internal investigation has progressed, and we've shared the results of our work to date with both the SEC and the Department of Justice. And we are responding to their request for additional information. At this time, we can't predict how or when the matter will be resolved. I'm sure you'll appreciate that I can't provide further details at this point. 
Let me now comment on results in the balance of Asia where we saw strong sales growth in 2014. The Philippines, Thailand and Malaysia all delivered very strong revenue growth based on strong execution and innovation, underpinned our progress in all 3 countries. GDP growth remains strong across most of Southeast Asia, and the fundamental growth drivers for the category and Mead Johnson remain intact. EBIT for the Asia segment increased as revenue grew in 2014, but the resulting improvement was substantially offset by higher dairy cost that adversely impacted profit margins. 
Turning now to Latin America. Constant dollar revenue growth -- rose 14% in the fourth quarter of 2014 over the same quarter of 2013. Volume was up 3%. Improved pricing added 11 points of growth to the quarter. On a constant dollar basis, revenue was up 16% for the full year. Volume increased by 6%, and higher pricing contributed 10 percentage points to our growth. 
Foreign exchange movements once again impacted results for the segment. The strengthening dollar and resulting depreciation of local currencies reduced U.S. dollar sales by 15% in full year 2014, more than offsetting pricing gains. Most of our pricing gains were seen in Venezuela and Argentina. Despite this, in aggregate, we failed to fully offset currency weakness through price in these 2 high-inflation countries. 
Our performance across Mexico, the Caribbean and Central America provided a highlight within the region. We experienced strong revenue growth as we relaunched our Enfa franchise and introduced several new products towards the end of the year. Despite a tough economic environment in Brazil, we continue to grow our market share of the infant formula category there. Our children's business, which is more sensitive to economic fluctuations, had a difficult year however. And overall performance was less strong than it has been in recent years. EBIT for our Latin America segment compared unfavorably to prior-year quarter and full year. This was primarily due to the foreign exchange, and to a lesser extent, higher dairy cost. 
Let me now turn to our North America/Europe segment. In the fourth quarter of 2014, the North America/Europe segment delivered stronger-than-expected revenue growth. Constant dollar revenue was up 14% on prior year's quarter. And on a full year basis, constant dollar revenue increased 10% over 2013. Pete will provide further detail on this in a moment. The improved performance in North America and Europe was driven by strong share gains in infant formula as well as continued progress towards our stated goal of building a strong and profitable children's business with Enfagrow. We've invested substantially behind our North American brands in recent years, and we're now reaping the rewards. 
Sales of Enfagrow grew by over 20% in 2014 with demand rising rapidly in both the United States and Canada. While we rarely highlight our European business due to its relative size, I should mention that European profits improved substantially in 2014, and revenue growth was similar to that of North America. Our 2012 restructuring that we focused our efforts on our specialty business continues to pay off. Revenue growth was driven by share gains within a growing European allergy segment. EBIT margin in the segment improved substantially during the year driven by pricing gains and our turnaround in Europe. 
Before I hand over to Pete, let me now wrap up with our perspective of 2015. We look forward to another year of solid sales and earnings growth despite a tougher global macroeconomic climate. There are 3 important factors to keep in mind as we think about 2015. Firstly, let me address our expectations for revenue growth. We expect revenue growth in constant dollars of around 7%. We expect lower commodity costs and currency-related inflationary pressure on governments in many countries will combine to create a more difficult pricing environment even as we introduce innovations. Conversely, we are hopeful a stronger economic climate in the United States will allow us to continue to recover through price the investments made in innovation and product improvement over the past 5 years. 
Secondly, going forward, we expect our profit margins to benefit from lower commodity costs and a weakening euro. That said, approximately 75% of our sales are booked in currencies other than the U.S. dollar, while many of our costs are dollar denominated. So despite our expectation for margin improvement as we move through 2015, there'll be some offsetting effect. 
Thirdly and finally, we intend to continue to invest behind product innovation and marketing initiatives at a level consistent with our growth ambition. I'm excited with our plans for 2015 and look forward to sharing more details with you as we move through the year. 
So to repeat, we expect full year constant dollar sales growth to be around 7%. Pricing will likely make a smaller contribution to sales growth than it did in 2014. And based on some improvement in expected profit margins, we estimate non-GAAP earnings per share for 2015 to be in the range of $3.90 to $4. 
I will now turn the call over to Pete, who will provide more detailed commentary on our financial results and our outlook. I'll then return to provide some closing remarks before we field your questions. Pete, over to you.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kasper, and good morning, everyone. Kasper addressed constant dollar sales growth, so I'll focus first on foreign exchange. There's been a lot of press about foreign exchange accompanying earnings reports for multinationals, so I'm going to get in
componenttext:
Thanks, Kasper, and good morning, everyone. Kasper addressed constant dollar sales growth, so I'll focus first on foreign exchange. There's been a lot of press about foreign exchange accompanying earnings reports for multinationals, so I'm going to get into a bit more detail in that topic than I might otherwise have done. While there's no doubt that FX has become a more significant headwind, please keep in mind that our EPS guidance range still anticipates good leverage of sales growth. After discussing currency effects, I'll walk down the income statement providing highlights on both our 2014 results and our 2015 guidance. I'll then share a few noteworthy items on our balance sheet and cash flow. Unless otherwise noted, my comments will be on a non-GAAP basis. 
As Kasper detailed, constant dollar sales grew by 9% in 2014. Foreign exchange reduced full year sales growth by 4%, resulting in reported sales growth of 5%. The dollar started to strengthen noticeably in the third quarter, and this trend accelerated in the fourth quarter. The stronger dollar reduced EPS by about $0.28 during the full year of 2014, including both translation and balance sheet remeasurement impacts, more than double the impact we experienced in 2013. Note that we mitigate the impact of foreign exchange through higher pricing. 
There were 2 critical factors at work. First, we saw very significant devaluations in Venezuela, and to a lesser extent, in Argentina. These 2 markets accounted for almost 2/3 of the total earnings degradation from foreign exchange in 2014. Despite taking significant price increases in both markets, we could not fully offset the impact of rapidly weakening currencies. 
The second factor relates to the Chinese renminbi. In the past, I pointed out the natural currency protection from the ongoing strengthening of the renminbi when other currencies in Asia and Latin America devalued. This was not the case in 2014. For the first time since our IPO, the renminbi weakened slightly against the dollar on a full year basis. In the prior 3 years from 2011 through 2013, the renminbi strengthened by about 2.5% on average, so there was no favorable offset from this important currency last year. 
We expect to see adverse foreign exchange impacts continue in 2015 based on the recent and pronounced strengthening of the dollar across a very broad basket of currencies in Asia and Latin America. A weaker euro helps to reduce the impact on our bottom line since we export product into China and Hong Kong from the Netherlands. But the breadth and magnitude of the decline elsewhere outweighs the euro benefit. 
Over the last 3 months, the dollar strengthened by an average of about 3% for the company. Practically every market was affected including China. As a result, we believe our largest market will continue to contribute to unfavorable foreign exchange in 2015. If exchange rates remain at their current level, but allowing for some continued modest devaluation in Venezuela and Argentina later in the year, we expect foreign exchange to lower sales growth by 4% in 2015. On the same basis, earnings per share would be reduced by at least $0.13 relative to 2014. Another 1% strengthening of the dollar against all currencies where we operate would lead to further reductions in EPS of about $0.05 per share on a full year basis, just from translation only. 
I want to mention a bit more about Venezuela. The conditions in Venezuela continue to deteriorate with the drop in oil prices. You may recall, we used the SICAD I exchange rate, which currently stands at about VEF 12 to the dollar to translate our financial statements. For Mead Johnson, the government provided access to dollars at the official rate of 6.3, which results in a favorable cash settlement currency gain when these funds are received. We use these dollars to pay our Mexican manufacturing operation for products imported into Venezuela. 
We believe there will be a reduction in these cash settlement FX gains in 2015 for 2 reasons: First, we enter the new year with a lower intercompany payable from our Venezuelan subsidiary; and second, over the past quarter, we've seen a slowdown in access to U.S. dollars and expect this to continue given the significant revenue shortfall faced by the government. The complicated situation in Venezuela, by itself, is another significant foreign exchange downside risk for the company. 
Turning to profitability. We delivered a gross margin of 61.9% in the fourth quarter, up sequentially from 60.2% in the third quarter as we started to realize the benefit from lower dairy prices. On a full year basis, gross margin was in line with our guidance at 61.9%, yet down 170 basis points from 2013 as higher dairy costs, adverse foreign exchange and Singapore start-up costs more than offset higher prices and productivity efforts. Cost savings from productivity stood at about 3.5% of our cost of goods sold, slightly above our 3% target. 
Turning to 2015. We expect gross margin will approach 63.5% for the full year, consistent with the level seen in 2013. Lower dairy costs are the key driver. Keep in mind that spot dairy prices are reflected in our cost of goods sold on a 7-month lag. We expect continued quarterly improvement in gross margin on a sequential basis as we progress through 2015. Higher dairy prices last year affected Asia more than any other geographic segment. As a result, the 2015 gross margin improvement will be most visible in that region. 
Finally, costs associated with the start-up of the Singapore manufacturing facility reduced earnings by about $0.10 per share in 2014. Given that the plant is now operational and increasing throughput steadily, we expect to see that expense cut in half to about $0.05 in 2015. We anticipate a further reduction in start-up expenses in 2016 when the plant reaches full capacity. 
Last year, operating expenses came in at 38% of sales, down 160 basis points from 39.6% in 2013. On a constant dollar basis, we increased demand generation investments, including advertising and promotion, sales force and marketing expenses by about $50 million on top of record spending in 2013. But these investments still grew at a lower rate than reported sales. It is worth noting that R&D spending continue to be strong at 2.5% of sales last year. 
Other income and expense also drove favorable operating expenses measured on a percent of sales basis in 2014 versus the prior year. The cash settlement currency gains in Venezuela that I mentioned earlier was one item at work along with the benefit associated with the sale of our equity interest in the Saudi joint venture to Almarai. For 2015, we intend to reinvest a portion of our higher gross margins back into the business through higher demand generation spending. In addition, we will not have the benefit from the Almarai sales and we expect lower cash settlement gains in Venezuela. As a result, operating expenses are anticipated to come in around 39% of sales. 
Given the assumptions I just outlined about both gross margins and operating expenses, 2015 EBIT margins should approach 24.5%, up from 23.8% in 2014 and the highest EBIT margin for the company since 2009. 
Looking at taxes, our non-GAAP effective tax rate or ETR was 22.5% in 2014, which included a $0.05 per share nonrecurring tax benefit that we recognized in the third quarter. Without that benefit, the normalized rate would have been around 23.5%. That's a bit better than our prior guidance for 2014 and added a $0.01 or $0.02 to fourth quarter EPS versus earlier expectations. Our 2015 global ETR is estimated to come in about 24%. This anticipates increased benefits from the new Singapore facility but also our plans to repatriate more earnings from outside the U.S. 
Moving on to interest expense. 2014 was a productive year on the financing front. We refinanced $500 million in notes due in late 2014 with new 30-year bonds at a very attractive rate, significantly extending our long-term debt maturity. We also increased our revolver from $500 million to $750 million while securing lower fees and extending the maturity in additional 3 years. In 2015, we anticipate interest expense will be just under $60 million. 
To summarize our 2015 non-GAAP guidance, we expect constant dollar sales growth of 7% this year with foreign exchange reducing sales growth by 4%. As a result, reported sales would increase by about 3%. 
Turning to segment performance. 2015 constant dollar sales growth in Asia should be similar to the company's overall level of growth around 7%, which is consistent with 2014. However, we expect that pricing will contribute less to growth in 2015 on lower commodity cost, while volume growth will be stronger. As a result, the quality of our growth in Asia should improve. In Latin America, we anticipate that constant dollar sales growth will be in the low to midteens. 
Turning to North America/Europe. During 2014, we added 2 new WIC contracts, gained non-WIC market share for infant formula and increased our distribution for Enfagrow. We do not expect to see the same gains in 2015. While we obviously strive for higher market share, the unprecedented 2014 performance is not likely to repeat. In addition, we believe that a few retailers built their inventory late in the year, which contributed to our strong fourth quarter results. As a result, we're forecasting 2015 growth for North America/Europe at a rate below that for the company on a constant dollar basis. 
Non-GAAP earnings are expected to be in the range of $3.90 to $4 per share, growth of about 4% to 7%. The lower end of our range assumes a slightly more pessimistic foreign exchange environment, among other factors while still allowing EPS leverage relative to sales. Please note that we expect tougher comparisons in the first half of 2015. This is due in part to more favorable performance in the first half of 2014 both in China and with a more favorable exchange rate environment. The timing of capacity expansions will help comparisons to a greater extent in the second half of the year. 
Just a quick comment on the specified cost excluded from our non-GAAP results. We saw an unfavorable $0.13 per share hit from our mark-to-market pension liabilities in the quarter. This is largely attributed to the adoption of new actuarial mortality tables that's required of most companies. In addition, further softening in interest rates also had an impact. 
Wrapping up with our balance sheet and cash flow. Our cash balance was $1.3 billion at the end of 2014, up about $250 million from the prior year. Note that cash held in the United States was about $215 million, down from $360 million in the prior year. This is what drives the need for greater cash repatriation from abroad during 2015. 
Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow less capital expenditures, was $607 million during 2014, up 7% from the prior year. The change was mainly from lower capital spending and higher earnings as we completed the Singapore construction midyear. Higher cash flow in 2014 allowed us to increase our dividend by double digits to $1.50 per share. For 2015, capital spending is estimated about $175 million, consistent with our longer-term target of about 4% of sales. Depreciation and amortization expense is expected to be around $100 million, up from $92 million in 2014 as we'll have a full year of depreciation on the Singapore facility. 
With that, I'll now turn the call back to Kasper.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pete. As I think about our achievements in 2014, I reflect on a year in which we relaunched our Enfa franchise in many markets with new improved formulations and a fresh look. We expanded our liquids portfolio into several new markets in Asia a
componenttext:
Thank you, Pete. As I think about our achievements in 2014, I reflect on a year in which we relaunched our Enfa franchise in many markets with new improved formulations and a fresh look. We expanded our liquids portfolio into several new markets in Asia and Latin America, and we completed the rollout of our key specialty formulas across Asia. We also continue to build our capabilities, opening a new spray drying facility in Singapore and breaking ground on other important capacity expansion projects in both Europe and the United States. As we look forward to another exciting year for our company, we continue to execute against our core growth strategies and stated priorities, our commitment to continuous innovation behind our core products and plans, the growth of our children's nutrition franchise and the continued investment in the quality and relevance of our products to children and parents. We continue to pursue these strategies organically and through selected inorganic activities when opportunities arise. 
I'd like to conclude my comments by acknowledging the exceptional efforts of my Mead Johnson colleagues around the globe. Together, we delivered strong performance in 2014, and we are committed to driving further growth in 2015. 
So with that, I'd like to hand the call back to our operator, Shannon, so we can open the lines to your questions. Shannon, back to you.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Bryan Spillane of Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Bryan Spillane of Bank of America.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I've got a question just -- or 2 questions, I guess, related to  China. One was just, Kasper, you had mentioned in your prepared remarks that you were monitoring the Enfagrow launch and that retailers I guess were -- with tightened inventory or ma
componenttext: I guess I've got a question just -- or 2 questions, I guess, related to  China. One was just, Kasper, you had mentioned in your prepared remarks that you were monitoring the Enfagrow launch and that retailers I guess were -- with tightened inventory or maintaining tight inventory levels based on some assumption maybe that the market is slowing. So if you could just expand upon that just in terms of whether there's been a material slowing in the market, whether that's just a conservative stand. And then just related to that, if I remember correctly, when you launched Enfa or when you launched a new product in China, it didn't come with a price increase. And with the exchange rates maybe working against you in China, is there a chance potentially to put -- to contemplate some price increases, if that's sustainable?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bryan, those are excellent questions. Maybe just for the benefit of the rest of the audience, just mention that we didn't relaunch just our Enfagrow product, but we restaged really the whole Enfa range in late October or early November. And obviously, we
componenttext: Bryan, those are excellent questions. Maybe just for the benefit of the rest of the audience, just mention that we didn't relaunch just our Enfagrow product, but we restaged really the whole Enfa range in late October or early November. And obviously, we are staying very closely to how that's -- that is performing. It's a wee bit early to sort of commit ourselves to giving you an indication of performance, but we are pretty confident based on what we've seen in other markets around the world. My comment regarding reduction in retail inventory, I think, is fairly consistent with what you've heard many other companies in the consumer products space allude to over the past few weeks and months. It's clear that this slowdown in the Chinese economy is causing most businesspeople, including retailers, to take a more cautious stance. And I think it's also fair to say that the retail trade in China, but really right across Asia, has for several years been characterized by very, very high levels of inventory. I'm glad to say that I think we are at the more conservative end of the spectrum when it comes to allowing retailers to buy inventory. So I'm not trying to signal any significant, sort of abrupt change in the coming months, but we are clearly seeing retailers manage their purchases quite carefully. So I hope that helps a little bit.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then just in terms of pricing, just if the exchange rate works against you over time, is there a chance just the prospects to try to price some of that away?
componenttext: That's helpful. And then just in terms of pricing, just if the exchange rate works against you over time, is there a chance just the prospects to try to price some of that away?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think to be candid, Bryan, I think it's going to be challenging, at least in the first half of the gear. Because I think authorities around the world, as their currencies weaken relative to the dollar, are likely to experience sort of inflationary press
componenttext: I think to be candid, Bryan, I think it's going to be challenging, at least in the first half of the gear. Because I think authorities around the world, as their currencies weaken relative to the dollar, are likely to experience sort of inflationary pressure in the general economy. So they are likely to take a strong interest in pricing, I think. And then secondly, they are likely to be very tuned in to the fact that commodity costs have come down. So though the dynamic you are reflecting might lead you to conclude that we would see some pressure on our margins, I think we are going to be helped to a great degree by falling commodity prices as we move through the year.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Yes, that's a fair statement.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't want to get into it. And just keep in mind too, as we've gone through 2014, we pointed out that we had a couple of points of price benefit even on the company level from Venezuela and Argentine inflation. It's been very significant there, so
componenttext: Well, I don't want to get into it. And just keep in mind too, as we've gone through 2014, we pointed out that we had a couple of points of price benefit even on the company level from Venezuela and Argentine inflation. It's been very significant there, so that will affect that number, too.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And kind of the heart of what I want to understand today is the fourth quarter volume decline in the Asian segment of negative 2, I kind of generally think that investors don't ever expect to see a negative volume number in that line just given the
componenttext: Okay. And kind of the heart of what I want to understand today is the fourth quarter volume decline in the Asian segment of negative 2, I kind of generally think that investors don't ever expect to see a negative volume number in that line just given the emerging market nature there, rising in the middle class, the movement to infant formula from breast feeding. Can you talk about what's the underlying growth rate kind of net of all these effects? And maybe if I could just throw one other piece of confusion into this question we hear the local companies in China talk greatly about the slowdown in the category, but they appear to be being very negatively affected by the growth of the Internet channel, which appears to be to the favor of the multinational companies like Mead. So can you work this into the answer in terms of kind of what underlying growth ought to be for maybe the category and then for Mead on a go-forward basis?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. I'll attempt to answer a couple of those things. Firstly, I should point out that volume growth on a full year basis was plus 2%. But irrespective of that, I think we would still ordinarily expect to see higher volume growth, which I think is
componenttext: Yes, David. I'll attempt to answer a couple of those things. Firstly, I should point out that volume growth on a full year basis was plus 2%. But irrespective of that, I think we would still ordinarily expect to see higher volume growth, which I think is really your point, and I concur with that. It's really entirely driven by the change in the China environment. We've said -- I think we've been fairly explicit about the fact that we are -- we are not currently participating as strongly as we would like in the highest growth channels, particularly the e-commerce channel, which is favoring heavily imported brands mostly out of Europe and Australia, New Zealand. And then secondly, the slowing environment in China is clearly sort of hitting everybody. So it's really a China-specific dynamic, and I'd be even more explicit about that. And I would say it is a Mainland China-specific dynamic where as I would say, the rest of Asia has been pretty much business as usual, which as you know is very positive.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ken Goldman of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ken Goldman of JPMorgan.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: You talked about ripping the rewards in the U.S. from past investments, but you're also going to, I think invest a lot of the windfall from cheaper dairy into marketing. So can you just talk a little bit about that balance how we think about that. I under
componenttext: You talked about ripping the rewards in the U.S. from past investments, but you're also going to, I think invest a lot of the windfall from cheaper dairy into marketing. So can you just talk a little bit about that balance how we think about that. I understand on the one hand, you don't  want all the gross margin to flow to the bottom line. But on the other hand, the Russian-diminishing marginal returns on each extra dollar of marketing. So any color there on how much you plan on reinvesting and your thoughts behind that would be appreciated?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean we really plan our investments in demand creation with a sort of bottoms-up approach. So we don't spend money just because it becomes available. We spend what we think it takes to execute our marketing and innovation program at the right kind of qu
componenttext: I mean we really plan our investments in demand creation with a sort of bottoms-up approach. So we don't spend money just because it becomes available. We spend what we think it takes to execute our marketing and innovation program at the right kind of quality. I think we will continue to invest in the U.S. market in particular. I think we've seen in the last 12 months or so that our persistence during 5 years of downturn where we really did not materially strengthen our investments is now -- those investments are now paying off. Without those, we wouldn't see the growth, particularly in our children's franchise that we are seeing. And I'd venture to say we wouldn't see the share gains in our infant formula business that we are seeing. So we remain committed to that. I don't want to get into giving a specific range of A&P spends because I think it will fluctuate up and down from individual quarters and individual years, but I think we're investing at a healthy level to support our growth ambition, and we'll continue to do that. I'm sorry if that sounds a little bit evasive. It's not intended to be but...

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, that's okay. I'm going to try and pin you down a little bit with a follow-up, if I can.
componenttext: No, that's okay. I'm going to try and pin you down a little bit with a follow-up, if I can.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: If you look at historical trends and where we've been in the last couple of years and so, we're not going to be dramatically different from that.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: So help me understand that and I'll let it go after this, but your gross margin is going to go up by 160-ish, 150, 160 basis points. Your operating margin's going to go up by, what is that, 70 basis points roughly? So where's the delta? Just help us, help me understand a little bit where that delta is and the spending that you're adding to SG&A.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: What I had said in my comments, you're going to expect to see operating expenses in total go up by about 100 basis points. And that reflects demand generation spending, not just A&P, sales force, digital marketing efforts, things like that across the comp
componenttext: What I had said in my comments, you're going to expect to see operating expenses in total go up by about 100 basis points. And that reflects demand generation spending, not just A&P, sales force, digital marketing efforts, things like that across the company.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Warren Ackerman of Societe Generale.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Warren Ackerman of Societe Generale.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Warren Ackerman here of SocGen. Could I turn the questioning a bit to North America? It was an amazing year for you guys in North America/Europe, up 10% -- up 14% in the quarter. You flagged 3 factors in your prepared remarks: share gains, expanding toddl
componenttext: Warren Ackerman here of SocGen. Could I turn the questioning a bit to North America? It was an amazing year for you guys in North America/Europe, up 10% -- up 14% in the quarter. You flagged 3 factors in your prepared remarks: share gains, expanding toddler and U.S. retail inventory adjustments. Just wondered whether you could maybe break those out first in the quarter. And then on the guidance on North America for 2015, you're talking about below the group average of 7%. Is that just a comp issue? Or is there any thing else going on in terms of the moving parts?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, with regard to the North American growth, you're talking about the quarter. We did see heavier shipments at the end of the month. And it's very hard for us to say, is that in inventory build or not. We think some piece of it would, would be. And it'
componenttext: Sure, with regard to the North American growth, you're talking about the quarter. We did see heavier shipments at the end of the month. And it's very hard for us to say, is that in inventory build or not. We think some piece of it would, would be. And it's probably on the order of about $10 million, which we'd say, maybe 5 points of growth or so in the quarter will be that. About 1% for the full year, nothing big. Toddler continues -- Enfagrow continues to grow. Kasper mentioned 24% for that, it's roughly 10% of our business, so you're getting a couple of points from that. And then the rest will be share gains both WIC from those 2 new contracts that we had, the biggest of which was Florida, and also non-WIC share. Then what is your second question, I'm sorry?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It was just about the comp. You're saying North America, Europe will be below the average for 2015. Is that just because of the comp in terms of the distribution build of toddler? Or are there any other kind of factors, which means that North America is s
componenttext: It was just about the comp. You're saying North America, Europe will be below the average for 2015. Is that just because of the comp in terms of the distribution build of toddler? Or are there any other kind of factors, which means that North America is still going to be a good number, but obviously much less good than what we saw in '14?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, what I mentioned is the share gains that we experienced were exceptional. And you cannot count and we cannot count on adding that much incremental share every year. So we added the Florida WIC contract. We don't sit here and anticipate somet
componenttext: Yes, I think, what I mentioned is the share gains that we experienced were exceptional. And you cannot count and we cannot count on adding that much incremental share every year. So we added the Florida WIC contract. We don't sit here and anticipate something that quite honestly to be added to the portfolio. And you get some non-WIC share gains from that as well. So it's the combination of the share gains. Distribution for Enfagrow was a piece of it, which won't repeat. And then there was about 1 point or so coming from that retail or inventory build. So that when you add all those together will bring it in place.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Your next question is from Robert Moskow of Credit Suisse.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was trying to look at the Asia guidance for 2015, and it appears to assume volume growth mid-single digit, maybe 5% or so to get to the 7% that you're talking about for the segment. Are you expecting a pickup in category growth in Mainland China? Or is
componenttext: I was trying to look at the Asia guidance for 2015, and it appears to assume volume growth mid-single digit, maybe 5% or so to get to the 7% that you're talking about for the segment. Are you expecting a pickup in category growth in Mainland China? Or is this just easier comps against the retailer inventory reductions that were happening? How conservative or aggressive do you think this overall assumption for Asia top line?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we think the range of numbers that you're describing is more consistent with what we have historically been able to deliver in Asia net of these kind of readjustments that we've seen in 2014. So I think, Robert, that, that's entirely achievable. We
componenttext: Well, we think the range of numbers that you're describing is more consistent with what we have historically been able to deliver in Asia net of these kind of readjustments that we've seen in 2014. So I think, Robert, that, that's entirely achievable. We do, of course, expect to have some tailwind from the comps in the second half of the year consistent with what we've said about the retailer inventory reductions in China. But that, of course, presupposes that we're at the end of that. So I just want to throw in that caveat.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I would add that, remember, we're going to have tougher comps in the first half of the year as well. So I think from an overall perspective, I don't consider that guidance to be necessarily easy to achieve.
componenttext: And I would add that, remember, we're going to have tougher comps in the first half of the year as well. So I think from an overall perspective, I don't consider that guidance to be necessarily easy to achieve.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I would agree, and I think that's one of the pushbacks that we got on the stock is that with China slowing, there may even be a spillover into GDP growth in other Asian markets. And have you gone as deep to figure out or think through whether you
componenttext: Yes, and I would agree, and I think that's one of the pushbacks that we got on the stock is that with China slowing, there may even be a spillover into GDP growth in other Asian markets. And have you gone as deep to figure out or think through whether you need to gain share against in order to achieve this top line in Asia? Because I think the first half is also tough because you also have continued comparisons against the recalls last year as well. Or have you held the share sure that you picked up in China? A lot of questions there.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Robert, I think those are good points to discuss. I mean the first point I'd make at a sort of macroeconomic level is just to observe that the rest of Asia is not very closely linked to China from a trade perspective. So as you know, much to the consterna
componenttext: Robert, I think those are good points to discuss. I mean the first point I'd make at a sort of macroeconomic level is just to observe that the rest of Asia is not very closely linked to China from a trade perspective. So as you know, much to the consternation of many of the Asian governments, there's relatively little trade inside of Asia. So we think GDP growth in the rest of Asia is more likely to be driven by -- in a recovery in Europe and the performance of the U.S. economy, which is where the bulk of their exports go. So I think we feel -- obviously, we feel confident in the guidance. Otherwise, we would have given different guidance. But I think you are thinking about it in the right way from a kind of volume-versus-price perspective, and we'll continue to keep you posted. We are very mindful of the fact that we will face headwind in translating our revenue into U.S. dollars and that, that will have a sort of a significantly offsetting effect on any margin improvement that would otherwise come from commodity prices reducing.,

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from John Baumgartner of Wells Fargo.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kasper, it's been a little over a year now since Mead increased its efforts behind toddler milk in the U.S. And I guess given where you are right now, just wondering if you could speak a bit in terms of trial and repeat purchases versus your expectations.
componenttext: Kasper, it's been a little over a year now since Mead increased its efforts behind toddler milk in the U.S. And I guess given where you are right now, just wondering if you could speak a bit in terms of trial and repeat purchases versus your expectations. And then I guess to the extent that you're seeing some pretty good sales in your current outlets, any opportunity to go and expand distribution with your new outlets more than your initial plan?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. I mean as I alluded to in my prepared remarks, Enfagrow, now for the second year in a row, grew by over 20% versus prior year. So I feel delighted with the payoff we are getting on that investment or that strategic decision to put incremental d
componenttext: Yes, John. I mean as I alluded to in my prepared remarks, Enfagrow, now for the second year in a row, grew by over 20% versus prior year. So I feel delighted with the payoff we are getting on that investment or that strategic decision to put incremental dollars behind that initiative. We think it's probably the biggest opportunity for both the U.S. business, and frankly speaking, for the industry in total. We're happy with the support we are now beginning to get from retailers, and we'll continue to invest behind it. We were assisted to some degree in 2014 by distribution increases as a result of our delivery of strong growth in 2013. We think we have probably exhausted most of that upside, so we're not -- I think Pete mentioned it briefly in his statement. And also, we are not anticipating additional distribution increase in 2015, but we are expecting continued momentum in existing outlets. And though I'm not prepared to share with you the exact details in terms of trial and repeat, I can only say that as a general rule, we would not invest strongly in a product where we did not see strong repeat purchase scores.

componenttext: Okay, got it. And then one more, Kasper, if we look at your R&D spending, and it's been rising pretty consistently with 4 new pediatric nutrition centers in the last 4 years. Should we expect some bit of acceleration on how you're bringing new products to the market? Perhaps accelerated the time line and get a little bit better pricing from a mix perspective versus what you have done historically?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think our lead times are really driven by 2 different elements. I mean it's driven by, frankly speaking, how long it takes us to make up our minds about what we want to do, and then how long it takes us to execute. We are constantly working on getting o
componenttext: I think our lead times are really driven by 2 different elements. I mean it's driven by, frankly speaking, how long it takes us to make up our minds about what we want to do, and then how long it takes us to execute. We are constantly working on getting our information systems and our market research functions and processes to support faster decision making, and that's frankly the easier part to work on. The time to execution is largely driven by the regulatory framework in the countries in which we compete. And in that area, we have relatively limited scope for improvement that we are exploring options to shave that time frame. But I don't think that you should expect significant reductions in cycle time from us, much as we would all like to see that.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the higher R&D spending will just show up in better quality of innovation, not necessarily?
componenttext: So the higher R&D spending will just show up in better quality of innovation, not necessarily?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, it's in quality and in the range of innovations that we are able to bring to the market.
componenttext: Yes, I think, it's in quality and in the range of innovations that we are able to bring to the market.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Matthew Grainger of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Matthew Grainger of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to come back to China and the relaunch. If we look beyond the inventory dynamics and sort of the broader market slowdown that you've talked about, how would you characterize more generally the consumer reaction? And how you think it's impact
componenttext: I just wanted to come back to China and the relaunch. If we look beyond the inventory dynamics and sort of the broader market slowdown that you've talked about, how would you characterize more generally the consumer reaction? And how you think it's impacting market share trends in your core distribution channels? And just sort of a follow-on to that, e-commerce is definitely -- clearly, it's still a headwind. Is 2015 the year when you really start addressing this in a material way?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we certainly are driving e-commerce with substantial efforts, Matthew. It's hard to determine exactly when we will break through to the point that it provides a significant impact on our global results, but I can assure you that it's not for lack
componenttext: I think we certainly are driving e-commerce with substantial efforts, Matthew. It's hard to determine exactly when we will break through to the point that it provides a significant impact on our global results, but I can assure you that it's not for lack of effort. I think it's also very important that when you look as I think a number of times of these calls, as you look at these 4 primary channels that really exist in China, sort of the grocery trade in China, the baby store trade in China, the e-commerce channel and then the importation of product through Hong Kong, which are really the 4 channels that we think about when we look at China. It's very important that you don't think that these can be added together to arrive at a total market. There is a lot of cross-channel trading taking place between those channels. So to the extent that you'll see, for instance, rising sales in baby stores, you'll automatically see the same rise in the Internet channel because that is a major sourcing point for the baby store channel. So we are wary of that. We believe that it's likely that there will be some slowdown in the growth, particularly in the baby store channel. And that's consistent with what we've seen now really since the beginning of 2013. That channel went through a very rapid phase of expansion as additional stores were opened. But it's much less clear to me that on a same-store basis, that channel is growing as fast as it used to be. But the Internet channel remains interesting. It remains a high priority for us, and we have a number of initiatives in place that aim to strengthen our profile in that channel.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to go back, the impact of the restaging, is that having the intended effect on market share in baby stores or in mass?
componenttext: Okay. And then just to go back, the impact of the restaging, is that having the intended effect on market share in baby stores or in mass?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's a little bit early to say with -- we've sort of got about, I would say about 8 weeks till we start from the date we started -- maybe 12 from that date we started shipping. So I'm a little bit wary of committing myself to an answer right now oth
componenttext: Well, it's a little bit early to say with -- we've sort of got about, I would say about 8 weeks till we start from the date we started -- maybe 12 from that date we started shipping. So I'm a little bit wary of committing myself to an answer right now other than to say that in other countries where we've launched the same marketing mix, we've been very encouraged by the results we've seen. I should also mention as we talk about these 4 different channels in China that I'm obviously aware that other people share this same channel data in different ways with you. And it's your job to look at all the sources of data. I'd encourage you to add in the Hong Kong data into that channel data because it has a significant effect. And that channel is also growing faster than the China total average.

componenttext: Your next question comes from Eric Katzman of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Pete, a question on the Venezuela impact. I think you said there is a total of $0.28 of headwind between the balance sheet remeasurement and the translation. Can you split those 2? And my guess -- I mean obviously, this is very tough stuff. But the black
componenttext: Pete, a question on the Venezuela impact. I think you said there is a total of $0.28 of headwind between the balance sheet remeasurement and the translation. Can you split those 2? And my guess -- I mean obviously, this is very tough stuff. But the black market rates are probably multiples weaker than what you've been translating. I mean what kind of  risk are we kind of talking here to your guidance if you're forced to, I guess, deal with a much lower but a new rate?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first, if you look back when our transcripts come out, I indicated that the guidance that we have incorporates a modest devaluation, think 10% or so in Venezuela. And there's 3 things going on there, each of which costs us about $0.02 a share for th
componenttext: Well, first, if you look back when our transcripts come out, I indicated that the guidance that we have incorporates a modest devaluation, think 10% or so in Venezuela. And there's 3 things going on there, each of which costs us about $0.02 a share for the company. One is the impact of just translating our local currency results into dollars. One is the impact of the fact that we have more cash sitting there because the government hasn't made dollars available to us for the last 3 months. That means when a devaluation comes through, there's a bigger balance sheet remeasurement impact. And then the third of those cash settlement gains when we get cash paid -- cash basically -- the dollars made available to us at the rate of 6 versus the 12 that we're using for translation. Each of those is about $0.02 in '15 versus '14. So some is already included in there, but it could be worse than that, too. And certainly, the black market rates is much higher. In the past, I think it's been as high as 50 versus the 12. That's the government SICAD I exchange rate. But the volume on that isn't that high, quite frankly. And you would always expect, I think, to see a black market rate when currency isn't allowed to trade freely at a super high level. So -- but there is real exposure. And I would say we try to think through that in the guidance range that we've given. That's one item, but it certainly could be worse than what would be included in our guidance. And I don't want to quantify anything specifically for it at this point, but it could be noticeable.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one follow-up, Kasper. I'm sorry to make this the last question. But the SEC investigation, that was focused on the China pricing or promotion. And so you provided them with a response, and now they've asked for more. Is that what I sh
componenttext: Okay. And then just one follow-up, Kasper. I'm sorry to make this the last question. But the SEC investigation, that was focused on the China pricing or promotion. And so you provided them with a response, and now they've asked for more. Is that what I should conclude?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think I'm prepared to go much beyond what I've already said, except to say that I think the interactions we are having are -- as one would expect in these kinds of situations, we have -- we've said before that the internal investigation focused on
componenttext: I don't think I'm prepared to go much beyond what I've already said, except to say that I think the interactions we are having are -- as one would expect in these kinds of situations, we have -- we've said before that the internal investigation focused on certain expenditures that were made in connection with our marketing in China that may have breached the certain laws or regulations and was a breach of our own policies. But I was not trying to signal anything particular beyond what my exact words said. So beyond that, it's probably too early for me to try and get into it in more detail, Eric, because I'll run the risk of sort of guiding you or misleading you on that. We'll keep you all posted as this moves along. And obviously, it's a priority for us to try and bring it to resolution as soon as we can. Maybe I'll just finish by sort of adding on to your question about Venezuela and say that it's important to understand that our product category, just like the pharmaceutical imports here that go into Venezuela, is considered a high-priority category by the Venezuelan government, which indicates, I think, a likelihood that they will continue to strive to make foreign exchange available to importers of our category and that they would be very reluctant to see the category being priced at say, the black market rate, which would obviously have an enormous inflationary impact on product pricing in the marketplace. So though we are always cautious about Venezuela and careful, I don't want to send a signal that you should be kind of panicking about the topic.
