headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mead Johnson Nutrition First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Amanda, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded fo
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mead Johnson Nutrition First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Amanda, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kathy MacDonald, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed, Kathy.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Amanda. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Mead Johnson's First Quarter 2015 Conference Call. With me today are Kasper Jakobsen, our Chief Executive Officer; and Charles Urbain, our Interim Chief Financial Officer. As we start,
componenttext:
Thank you, Amanda. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining Mead Johnson's First Quarter 2015 Conference Call. With me today are Kasper Jakobsen, our Chief Executive Officer; and Charles Urbain, our Interim Chief Financial Officer. 
As we start, let me remind everyone that our comments will include forward-looking statements about our future results, including statements about our financial prospects and projections, commodity costs, currency fluctuations, pricing, taxes, capital spending, depreciation, amortization, new product launches, product quality, our growth initiatives and market conditions that constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the Safe harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. A more detailed explanation of our forward-looking statements will appear in the materials posted on our website in connection with today's conference call. Keep in mind that our actual results may differ materially from expectations as of today due to various factors, including those listed in our annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and current reports on Form 8-K, in each case, as filed with or furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission and our earnings release issued this morning, all of which are available upon request or on our website at meadjohnson.com. 
Today's comments will include discussion of non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation of these measures to comparable GAAP measures appears in this morning's earnings release posted on our website. In addition, any forward-looking statements represent our estimates only as of today and should not be relied upon as representing our estimates as of any subsequent date. While we may elect to update forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimates change. 
I will now turn the call over to Kasper.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathy. Good morning to all of you, and thank you for joining us on this morning's call. I'll begin with highlights of our first quarter global performance before discussing each of our operating segments and our expectations for the full year.
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathy. Good morning to all of you, and thank you for joining us on this morning's call. I'll begin with highlights of our first quarter global performance before discussing each of our operating segments and our expectations for the full year. Then Charles Urbain, who was recently appointed to the role of Interim Chief Financial Officer, will provide additional details on our financial performance. And finally, I'll return to provide a few summary remarks before we, as usual, open the line to your questions. 
Turning now to the first quarter of 2015. Constant dollar sales growth at 3% came in as expected, and we delivered record level non-GAAP earnings per share of $1.09 in the quarter. Price contributed 3% to revenue growth, while, as we left [ph] very strong quarters in the United States and China businesses, volume was unchanged from the same quarter of prior year. As our rate of revenue growth was significantly affected by performance in the 2014 base year, I firstly remind you that during the first half of 2014, we benefited significantly from competitors' supply disruptions in several large Asian markets, including China. Secondly, you'll remember we mentioned in earlier calls that retailers built inventory in the United States in the first quarter of 2014 to support certain weak contract gains, and again, in the fourth quarter of 2014, as they increase inventory ahead of the holiday season and plan promotions in January. These factors affected sales comparisons, and we saw orders lag consumer offtake in the latest quarter. We believe inventory levels are now back to normal and at sustainable levels. I'll provide further details in each of these factors in the segment discussion. 
Like many other companies with significant business outside of the United States, we saw a greater-than-anticipated adverse impact from a strengthening dollar on reported sales this quarter as we translated local currency revenue into dollars. As a result, U.S. dollar revenue for the quarter was 2% below prior year's quarter. The impact of foreign exchange on our income statement provides a good segue to a discussion of gross margin. As indicated in our January call, we saw gross margin improved significantly in the first quarter. The improvement was larger-than-anticipated as we benefited from weakness in the euro. This euro weakness helped mitigate the impact of currency swings on profitability and earnings. Charles will expand on this point later. Gross margin at 64% was up 210 basis points from the prior year quarter. In addition to our margin being helped by the weaker euro, we benefited from lower dairy input costs and the carryover effect of pricing taken through 2014. Similar to the pattern seen in most of our prior years, the timing of marketing initiatives meant that expenditure on advertising and promotion activities was relatively more modest, though still healthy, in the first quarter. 
We normally focus our discussion on non-GAAP earnings. However, I'd like to provide a brief update on our previously reported investigation into certain promotional activities within our China subsidiary. This item impacted our GAAP earnings in the quarter. In our last earnings call and in our 10-K filing, we stated that the company had shared the results of our investigation with both the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Justice. Our discussions with ACC regional staff have now progressed significantly since our last call. And in the first quarter of 2015, we've taken an accrual of $12 million. This amount reflects our best estimate of disclose fines and penalty costs that may be paid to resolve SEC concerns about alleged actions in China. I want to emphasize that discussions with both the SEC and the DOJ are ongoing and no settlement has been agreed to date. Therefore, there can be no assurance that the amount paid by the company to resolve this matter will not exceed the amount accrued to date or that other sanctions will not be imposed. 
Returning now to non-GAAP measures. Earnings per share were up 7% to $1.09 from $1.02 in the first quarter of 2014. Higher gross margin, lower operating expenses and a lower effective tax rate more than offset the impact on revenue of currency swings. I'm very encouraged by the resilience of our global business. Around the world, our teams are working hard to assist the external environment, appropriately adjust pricing where opportunities exist and drive productivity for efforts aggressively. 
Let me now comment on the performance of each of our reporting segments, starting with Asia. In the first quarter, constant dollar sales were in line with the prior year quarter. The quarter was adversely impacted by the effects on sales of several in Hong Kong. I'll return to this topic shortly. In aggregate, pricing gains of 1% within the segment were offset by slightly lower volume in the quarter. As expected, lower commodity costs have created an environment that discourages price increases. 
Let me now disaggregate our sales results and provide some color surrounding performance in key markets. Before I comment on other markets, including our business in Mainland China, let me draw your attention to the ongoing situation in Hong Kong. Many of you will be aware that the civil disturbance has had the effect of deterring mainland residents from visiting the territory. I remind you that the majority of our sales recorded in Hong Kong are to mainland visitors. Many businesses, including our own sales adversely impacted. As local protests and unrest have escalated, we have such slower uptake late in the quarter. Sales in the territory in recent weeks have been down around 20% versus our fourth quarter 2014 average. As you might imagine, we are closely monitoring the Hong Kong situation. We believe it'll be temporary and have great faith in the Hong Kong and China governance ultimately resolving the situation. That said, it's hard to predict exactly when the situation will return to normal. 
Let me now turn to our business in Mainland China. I'm encouraged that we made progress versus first quarter of 2014. We continue to improve our execution and refine our plans to strengthen our presence in channels where we currently are under-indexed. I previously said we are committed to creating a more flexible and more diversified business in China. This is largely about channel and sourcing strategy. I've also alluded to our desire to mitigate risks associated with the disruption to China/Hong Kong trade. Given recent events in Hong Kong, I'm very pleased to report that we have, this March, begun direct shipment of fully imported finished goods from our Netherlands facility into China. The product offered is identical to that showed in Hong Kong. Clearly fact, as produced in The Netherlands, and will be distributed through retailers, our own Tmall store and select baby stores. The launch is a culmination of work begun more than 12 months ago. In contrast, to some alternative Internet-based import models, importation will be done by the company itself in full compliance with Chinese quality standards, regulations and tax laws. Production capacity in our Netherlands facility will increase over the next few quarters and support our outlook for better growth in the second half of 2015. We look forward to providing consumers with more choice and more ways in which to interact with our business. 
You'll recall that we described inventory reductions in China in our January call as it related to the fourth quarter of 2014. We did not see further trade destocking in the latest quarter, and we are satisfied with consumer offtake of our recently restaged infant neuro complete products. 
Let me now comment on the balance of Asia. Our Philippines and Malaysia businesses delivered solid growth, driven by recent Nero complete launches and investment to support this innovation. The comparison for Vietnam was affected by the government imposed price reductions in mid-2014. Because of this prior year event, we expect performance metrics in the second half of 2015 to be more reflective of the progress we are making in the market. Our Thailand business also faced a difficult comparison from first quarter 2014 when we were benefiting from a recall in late 2013 by our biggest competitor. 
As you can tell, we saw a confluence of rather unusual events relating to the external environment. In combination, these events had a depressing effect on Asia's growth within this quarter. We are confident none of these are the lasting nature and that we will return to more normal growth rate in the second half of 2015. 
Turning now to Latin America. Constant dollar revenue rose 13% in the first quarter over the same quarter of prior year. Volume was up 3% and pricing added 10 points of growth. Foreign exchange movements continue to significantly impact results for the entire segment. The impact of a strengthening dollar and resulting depreciation of local currencies more than offset benefits from pricing gains. Pricing gains in the high inflation countries of Venezuela and Argentina contributed 900 basis points to the region's constant dollar growth rate. However, I'm pleased to note that both countries posted very solid double-digit volume growth and that the pricing gains in Argentina more than covered the impact of currency depreciation there. We continued to gain market share in most of the region with our premium Enfa brand. The brand has been supported by the same Neuro Complete innovation we are rolling out across Asia. As you are likely aware, economic conditions in Brazil have deteriorated sharply over the last year. As a result, we are seeing weakness in our Sustagen branded children's business. However, we continue to see strong growth in our Enfa franchise as we establish ourselves as the leading premium infant formula brand in Brazil. We saw strong rebounds in growth in both Colombia and Peru, both markets had a difficult year in 2014 when they addressed unique challenges. From cross-border trade in the case of Colombia and from a deteriorating customer relationship in the case of Peru, we've made good progress on putting both issues behind us. As a consequence, these businesses are seeing growth restored. 
Let me now turn to our North America/Europe segment. Constant dollar revenue in this segment was up 3% on the prior year's quarter driven by share gains in North America and price increases taken last year. Volume for the segment was unchanged compared to a strong base year. In the United States, volume was adversely impacted by a fourth quarter inventory build amongst leading retailers. The buildup late in 2014 was highlighted in our description of 2014 full year results as having contributed to a strong fourth quarter. This incremental inventory was fully consumed in the first quarter. And going forward, we expect sales to be more reflective of consumer demand. Secondly, sales in the first quarter of 2014, driven by certain WIC contract wins, resulted in a tough comparison this quarter. But importantly, we continue to gain market share in North America and Europe, and we now have market-leading positions in both the United States and Canada. In Europe, we made a decision to exit the Russia market. The Russian market is characterized by intense competition and high operating costs in a deteriorating economic environment. This action is consistent with our decision to focus on playing where we can win in Europe with focus on the allergy segment and making only selective plays in routine infant formula. This European strategy continues to payoff. Once again, we delivered double-digit constant dollar growth within a very large but shrinking European market. 
Let me now summarize our 2015 full year outlook. We continue to expect revenue growth around 7% on a constant dollar basis. In this segment, Charles will outline how we now anticipate a slightly stronger headwind from foreign exchange. However, as our cost structure continues to benefit from a weaker euro and lower dairy costs, we now have an improved outlook for gross margin for the full year, allowing us to maintain our non-GAAP earnings per share guidance in the range of $3.90 to $4. At the same time, we anticipate investing more aggressively in demand creation in the coming quarters. 
Before I hand the call over to Charles, let me briefly introduce him to those of you who don't know him. Charles began his career as an auditor at Price Waterhouse before serving in various tax and finance positions in. He then joined Bristol-Myers Squibb where he progressed through a series of local, regional and global treasury and finance roles before serving as Chief Financial Officer for Mead Johnson, while we were still a division within the Bristol-Myers Squibb company. From that road, he was promoted to various business leading roles and has run each of our operating regions prior to his most recent role as Chief Development Officer with responsibility for the company's M&A strategy, Human Resources and external affairs. Charles is being quick to pick up the reigns in his Interim CFO role and I know you'll enjoy your interactions with him. I'm very grateful that Charles has accepted this role as he's the perfect partner to help me build and mentor our next-generation finance organization. 
Charles, I hand the call over to you.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kasper, and good morning, everyone. Having had a long and enjoyable history with Mead Johnson, both on a commercial side and earlier in my career in finance, I'm very pleased to be in the Interim CFO role. I've met many of you in the early days
componenttext:
Thank you, Kasper, and good morning, everyone. Having had a long and enjoyable history with Mead Johnson, both on a commercial side and earlier in my career in finance, I'm very pleased to be in the Interim CFO role. I've met many of you in the early days [indiscernible] IPO and look forward to renewing those acquaintances. 
Kasper noted that our annual recorded dollar sales growth is expected to be slightly lower than previous guidance due to the impact of a stronger dollar and the translation of sales from local currencies. So I'll begin my prepared remarks with a brief discussion on foreign exchange as it impacts the quarter and outlook for the year. I will then provide highlights on key sales and expense items as I walk down the income statement. And I'll wrap up with comments in our balance sheet and cash flow. Unless otherwise noted that my comments will be on non-GAAP financials results and references to currency impacts are the effects of currency fluctuations on the translation of local currency financial statements into dollars. 
I'll move into a little discussion on foreign exchange. And this really represents our perspective on the foreign exchange environment, which is both pertinent to our discussion of the first quarter and balance of the year. We expect to see adverse foreign exchange conditions throughout 2015 as the dollar is generally forecasted to continue strengthening for the remainder of the year. In exchange rates, which remain at their current level and allowing for some continued modest devaluation in Venezuela and Argentina later in the year, we would expect foreign exchange to adversely affect growth by about 5% for the full year 2015. We experienced the similar impact from foreign exchange fluctuations in the first quarter. While it is clear that FX has become more significant headwind in the translation of sales, bear in mind that they are potential offsets. For example, a weaker euro helps to reduce the impact on our earnings. We have a large manufacturing operation in Europe that, when combined with a relatively local revenue base, makes us a net beneficiary of euro weakness. In the last several months, we have seen a significant slowdown in Venezuela and government approvals to exchange bolivars into dollars to pay for product that we bring into the country. Our expose bolivar cash balance is increasing as a result. We will consider limiting exports to Venezuela in order to manage our overall exposure to that country. We are closely monitoring our exposure and will continue to evaluate options with the most recent facts and circumstances. 
I will now begin my review of income statement, beginning with sales performance. For the first quarter, constant dollar sales grew 3%. Foreign exchange reduced sales growth by 5%, resulting in lower recorded sales of 2% versus the prior year quarter. The U.S. dollar continued to strengthen during the quarter, and its effect on the transition of local currencies impacted all reporting segments. The Venezuelan bolivar and the most recent -- the most, I beg your pardon, had the most significant adverse impact on sales, but most currencies were impacted, notably the Mexican peso and the Chinese renminbi. The impact of increased pricing, particularly in Latin America, partially offset the impact of weakening currencies. Volumes were in line with the prior year quarter on an aggregate basis. North America and Latin America sales grew in constant dollars and Asia sales were in line with the prior year as pricing gains offset small declines in volume. 
I'll now move on to factors discussing the impact -- impacting our gross profit. The gross margin was 64% in the first quarter, up 210 basis points sequentially from the fourth quarter of 2014, and slightly up from the first quarter of 2014. Lower dairy costs and the impact of pricing were the key drivers of this improvement. Pricing gains were primarily the impact of carryover prices taken last year. In our last conference call, we cautioned that with a lower dairy cost, it would be a more difficult pricing environment, even as we introduce innovation. This can already be seen in our first quarter results with pricing contributing 3% compared to last year's annual pricing gains of 5%. While dairy cost in aggregate have decreased quite sharply, it is worth noting that there is a range of cost reductions, depending upon the sourcing region, and several dairy components have, in fact, increased in cost. It should also be noted that nondairy commodities, which represent around 60% of our cost of commodities have in fact increased versus the prior year quarter. In total, the composite reduction in Mead Johnson commodity costs is in the high-single digits. Overall, we're very pleased with the strong gross margin in the first quarter and we now believe that the annual gross margin would be approximately 64%. Keep in mind that spot dairy prices are reflected in our cost of goods on a 7-month lag, so the current spot price takes us through November. 
Moving on to operating expenses. The first quarter's operating expenses of 36.6% of sales was similar to the prior year quarter of 36.9%. On a constant dollar basis, total demand generation investments rose at a similar rate to sales. Please note that salesforce marketing and other demand generating costs are included in this total. Within demand generating expenses, advertising and promotion spend was 13.2% of sales. Historically, these investments are lower in the first quarter of the year. We expect significantly higher investment level starting in the second quarter as additional innovation and promotional campaigns are launched. 
To conclude my discussion on operating expenses, for the full year, we reiterate our intention to reinvest a portion of our higher gross margins back into the business through higher demand generating spends. As a consequence, we anticipate our operating expenses for the year to be approximately 39% of sales with EBIT slightly above 24.5%. 
I will now briefly speak about our taxes and effective tax rate. Our non-GAAP effective tax rate or ETR was 22.5% in the first quarter compared to 25.7% in the prior year quarter. The lower rates is the result of a favorable geographic mix of earnings. On a full year basis, we expect the ETR to be slightly better than our previous guidance of 24% as the favorable earnings mix in Q4 -- in Q1 may not fully prevail for the full year. 
Moving on to factors which would impact EPS guidance on a non-GAAP basis. We continue to expect constant dollar sales growth of approximately 7% this year with the foreign currency reducing sales growth by about 5%. As a result, reported sales would increase by 2%. As you look at key factors which could impact EPS performance in the balance of the year, there are several factors which should be considered. An additional adverse foreign exchange impact on sales, which I referred to earlier, would reduce earnings, but is projected to be fully offset by slightly higher gross margins and a lower tax rate. We anticipate dairy cost tailwinds through the remainder of the year, but I again draw your attention to the other commodity offsets highlighted earlier in my remarks. Higher advertising and promotion spend in the remainder of the year, which will coincide with our key commercial activities. It is anticipated that investments will peak in quarter 2 with increases of at least 400 basis points above quarter 1 levels, taking our first half spend to around 15% of sales. Therefore, non-GAAP earnings guidance continues to be in the range of $3.90 to $4 a share, which is growth of about 4% to 7% versus 2014. The lower end of our range continues to achieve a more pessimistic foreign exchange environment, among other factors, while still delivering EPS leverage to sales. As a reminder, the growth rates and investment levels will continue to vary from quarter-to-quarter, reflecting the timing of our initiatives. 
I will now wrap up with a high level overview of the balance sheet. As an introductory comment, I believe it's worth noting that we have a very high return on invested capital with a return on invested capital greater than 40% and over 100% of net income converted into free cash flow in the first quarter. Of course, these measures can fluctuate from quarter-to-quarter, but this remains a remarkably strong balance sheet. Our cash balance is $1.4 billion as of March 31, 2015, up about $140 million from the prior year-end. Note that cash in the United States was about $205 million. Free cash flow, defined as operating cash flow less capital expenditures, was approximately $228 million in the first quarter after consuming $46 million in cash for capital investments. For the full year, capital spending expectations remain unchanged with about $175 million. This is consistent with our longer-term target of about 4% of sales. Depreciation and amortization expense is expected to be around $100 million for the full year. 
During the first quarter, our Board of Directors announced a 10% increase to our dividend, which should annualize to approximately $1.65 per share or $1.65 per share. As a result, dividends paid out in 2015 [ph] earnings are expected to run at a level above $320 million for the year. 
With that, I will now turn the call back to Kasper.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Charles. Charles mentioned that growth rates and investment levels will vary from quarter-to-quarter. In summing up today's call, I want to emphasize our focus on long-term growth. As we evaluate our performance, we continue to focus on the lon
componenttext:
Thank you, Charles. Charles mentioned that growth rates and investment levels will vary from quarter-to-quarter. In summing up today's call, I want to emphasize our focus on long-term growth. As we evaluate our performance, we continue to focus on the long-term and on strengthening of our portfolio. 
Over the past year or so, we've launched our newer complete innovation platform in 8 of our 10 largest markets. Wherever we introduced this innovation, it has helped strengthen our brand and our business. At the end of 2014, we introduced ready-to-drink products in several new key markets to diversify our offering to consumers and improve convenience. And just this month, we're introducing fully imported Enfa products into China to satisfy consumer desire for imported quality. Each of these initiatives speak to our focus on driving long-term growth through innovation. I want to recognize the many people throughout Mead Johnson who work on this important initiatives. 
During my recent webcast CAGR presentation, I outlined 4 key factors that were important to our outlook. I'd like to briefly reiterate these before we take your questions. Firstly, I mentioned the effect though foreign exchange with over 70% of our business in emerging markets and more than 75% of sales in non-U.S. dollar currencies. Any change in exchange rates has a significant impact on our top line. Secondly, we will benefit from favorable dairy input costs through much of 2015. Dairy prices impact our income statement with a 7 to 9-month lag. This give us -- this gives us and you great visibility to feature margins and allows us to plan investments accordingly. Finally, outside our 2 largest markets of China/Hong Kong and the United States, we are well diversified. However, these 2 markets account for more than half of our sales. Conditions in the United States continue to improve and our competitive position remains strong. Whereas the China/Hong Kong market is changing rapidly. We see some challenges in the near-term, especially in Hong Kong, but we see many more opportunities in the China market as it continues to evolve and change. And we're investing aggressively around the world and within China to take advantage of emerging consumer trends. 
As we begin our question-and-answer session, let me acknowledge your interest in the progress we are making towards resolution of our China related matter with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Justice. I ask for your understanding of my inability to go much beyond my prepared remarks and in answering any questions on this topic. As usual, we refer you to the company's disclosure within our 10-Q filing and commit to you that this is reviewed regularly to ensure that you get accurate and timely information. We expect full year constant dollar sales growth to be around 7% and non-GAAP earnings per share to be in the range of $3.90 to $4. 
In summary, we remain confident 2015 will see us once again deliver strong sales and earnings growth consistent with our long-term financial ambition. 
I'll now turn the call back to the operator so we can open the lines to your questions. Amanda, over to you.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from David Driscoll with Citi Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from David Driscoll with Citi Research.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions on China. The first one is regarding Hong Kong, as I understand it, the protest related to the local Hong Kong people's irritation with the parallel trade. You talked a lot about this sometime ago when there was other issues there when th
componenttext: Just 2 questions on China. The first one is regarding Hong Kong, as I understand it, the protest related to the local Hong Kong people's irritation with the parallel trade. You talked a lot about this sometime ago when there was other issues there when the government was going to change how many cans you can take across the border, but what I want to understand is are there out of stocks of infant formula at the Hong Kong stores? And is this a key problem for you? Or is this parallel trade beyond the infant formula category?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think what we see the discontent amongst local Hong Kong residents go probably much beyond cross-border trade. I think there are political motivations to do with this satisfaction about the level of sale, the general popular has in the selection of the
componenttext: I think what we see the discontent amongst local Hong Kong residents go probably much beyond cross-border trade. I think there are political motivations to do with this satisfaction about the level of sale, the general popular has in the selection of the Hong Kong Chief Executive, et cetera, which, you can imagine, I don't want to get too far into. But I think it is more than a trade issue, which makes it a little bit more difficult to predict when and where and how it will be resolved. I want to be very clear that there are no significant out of stock issues in Hong Kong. The industry I think has done a good and responsible job working with the authorities to resolve the out of stock issues that led to this initial restriction on parallel exports. Those issues are now being monitored regularly by the authorities and I know that the authorities are satisfied, I think, with the industry as a whole, but extremely satisfied with Mead Johnson's performance on this issue.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last question for me is just on China and your Internet strategy. So I'm still a bit confused as to how to have confidence that Mead will aggressively or play very well onto this whole massive movement for infant formula onto China Internet. I respe
componenttext: Okay. Last question for me is just on China and your Internet strategy. So I'm still a bit confused as to how to have confidence that Mead will aggressively or play very well onto this whole massive movement for infant formula onto China Internet. I respect your comments earlier about the shipments that began this month. But maybe you could just help us understand that is that enough and kind of why do you think it is enough if the shipments from The Netherlands facility will be kind of all it takes to get your Internet sales at levels commensurate with your market share in brick-and-mortar?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, David, I think it's all about making progress versus where we are. And I don't expect that there would be any immediate fix to the situation. However, I'm very confident that we are making progress. And we are closing gaps in our portfolio in Chi
componenttext: I think, David, I think it's all about making progress versus where we are. And I don't expect that there would be any immediate fix to the situation. However, I'm very confident that we are making progress. And we are closing gaps in our portfolio in China that will allow us to play better. So specifically what our strategy involves is working through the major e-tailers in China such as JD.com, et cetera, and offering these products on -- in our own Tmall store. But I also want you to bear in mind that there is a lot of cross-channel trade happening in China. So a large amount of the sales that you see reflected in data as being Internet sales, are in fact sold for further resale through the baby stores. And we obviously have the ability to go direct to those baby stores rather than going through some Internet-based intermediary. So I feel very good about the strategy. I have previously expressed concern about other business models of which I perceive to be more fragile and, perhaps, unsustainable that involve sort of export or importation into China through private individuals or product that is noncompliant and evasive of Chinese duties. We are not intending to, what shall we say, join that business model. We are trying to set other business model that will allow us to play in China over the long run.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Eric Katzman with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Eric Katzman with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, my first question, just to say a follow up, Charles. You mentioned something, maybe I missed it, but, so you got this decline in the dairy cost, and you said the other inputs are up. So your total inflation basket as it stands now in 2015 is expe
componenttext: I guess, my first question, just to say a follow up, Charles. You mentioned something, maybe I missed it, but, so you got this decline in the dairy cost, and you said the other inputs are up. So your total inflation basket as it stands now in 2015 is expected to be what?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: At the high-single digits on total commodities. If you're talking total commodities, it's down high-single digits.
componenttext: At the high-single digits on total commodities. If you're talking total commodities, it's down high-single digits.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So okay so the nondairy is up high-single digits, but the total basket is down?
componenttext: So okay so the nondairy is up high-single digits, but the total basket is down?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. No, let me try and clarify that for you. So our total cost of commodities on an apples-to-apples basis is up 9%. Dairy is down and nondairy is up slightly, and that includes agricultural oils, et cetera that are a more heavily used than dairy in our p
componenttext: No. No, let me try and clarify that for you. So our total cost of commodities on an apples-to-apples basis is up 9%. Dairy is down and nondairy is up slightly, and that includes agricultural oils, et cetera that are a more heavily used than dairy in our products. So 60% of our commodities are nondairy. But in aggregate, commodities will be up in high-single digits.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, to follow-up on David's question, Kasper, can you talk a little bit about, I realized kind of trying to see the end market in China is very, very difficult at the moment. But can you talk a little bit about the super premium produ
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, to follow-up on David's question, Kasper, can you talk a little bit about, I realized kind of trying to see the end market in China is very, very difficult at the moment. But can you talk a little bit about the super premium product? I think the last call or maybe with the call before that, you said that the super premium products were promoting pretty aggressively. Are you kind of still seeing that? Is that having a material impact in the market or on your product launch?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's not affecting our product launch. I mean, I can sort of -- I can expand a little bit more on the initiative that we have just launched into the market. As you know, we're not playing in the super high premium segment and I previously outlined the rea
componenttext: It's not affecting our product launch. I mean, I can sort of -- I can expand a little bit more on the initiative that we have just launched into the market. As you know, we're not playing in the super high premium segment and I previously outlined the reasons why and the conditions under which we would consider playing in that segment. The product we are launching in the month of April, so we're launching it right as we speak, is a fully imported product, which will be priced depending on the individual SKU, it will be priced 10% to 15% or so be above our locally manufactured product, which will allow us to pay the appropriate duties to bring it into China and remain off a highly competitive price and maintain a gross margin profile that is not dissimilar to our local business.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so I realized that you're not playing in the super premium and for what sounds like logical reasons, but are they still, that collective part of it, the category, are they still being price competitive? I think you had mentioned like taking...
componenttext: Okay. And so I realized that you're not playing in the super premium and for what sounds like logical reasons, but are they still, that collective part of it, the category, are they still being price competitive? I think you had mentioned like taking...

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we are seeing a fair amount of experimentation, David, I think, particularly by the people who have entered that segment later. I think they're experimenting still with ways in which they can offer a differentiated and competitive offering. And certa
componenttext: Yes, we are seeing a fair amount of experimentation, David, I think, particularly by the people who have entered that segment later. I think they're experimenting still with ways in which they can offer a differentiated and competitive offering. And certainly, some are testing to see whether a slightly more aggressive price point within that sort of bracket of price products would offer them an advantage.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bryan Spillane with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bryan Spillane with Bank of America.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I wanted to just maybe clarify something related to introducing the fully imported product into China and maybe tie it back to David Driscoll's question about the Internet strategy. I guess my impression has been part of the growth of the Internet
componenttext: I guess I wanted to just maybe clarify something related to introducing the fully imported product into China and maybe tie it back to David Driscoll's question about the Internet strategy. I guess my impression has been part of the growth of the Internet channel in China has been driven by the idea right by the availability of fully imported product, and it's easier in some ways to get it over the Internet than it is actually find it on the shelf at a reasonable price point. And I guess the idea now that you have a product that you can bring in fully imported and sell to neither channel, right? You could sell it into the baby stores. You can sell it online. Importantly, it's fully -- it's approved for sale, right, which is a big distinction I think. Isn't that really sort of the strategy here? As long as now you've got a product that you can bring in and you have full control of the distribution, you're different in terms of which channel it goes. But that's really sort of the big difference here and am I missing something there?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I could not take it any better than you've done, Bryan. I think it's a perfect understanding of our strategy. In summary, you have reason where I have highlighted both the difficulty of anticipating the evolution over the next 2 or 3 years of the Chin
componenttext: No, I could not take it any better than you've done, Bryan. I think it's a perfect understanding of our strategy. In summary, you have reason where I have highlighted both the difficulty of anticipating the evolution over the next 2 or 3 years of the China market. And hence, our emphasis on creating a flexible business model that allows us to be agile and adjust to the consumers' preferences essentially. And our goal would be to for us to be in an equally strong position whether the consumer wants to shop on the Internet or they want to go to a local baby store, of for that manner, they want to go to the local supermarket.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up to that and I don't want to take up too much time, it's just you've built a plant in Singapore, which, I guess, presumably would've been, at least partly would have been supplying, the idea would have been supplying Chin
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up to that and I don't want to take up too much time, it's just you've built a plant in Singapore, which, I guess, presumably would've been, at least partly would have been supplying, the idea would have been supplying China and now you're bringing product in from Europe instead. So does this at all affect the utilization of that plant? Or was that plant never really meant to service the Chinese market?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it doesn't affect the utilization of Singapore plant. Singapore plant, first of all, is not currently producing finished goods. It is simply producing base powder, which is an input for finishing plants in the rest of Asia, both in China and in the Ph
componenttext: No, it doesn't affect the utilization of Singapore plant. Singapore plant, first of all, is not currently producing finished goods. It is simply producing base powder, which is an input for finishing plants in the rest of Asia, both in China and in the Philippines, and in Thailand. Largely, what we did was that we built that plants to in-source base powder that was being manufactured for use in Asia by third-party manufacturers. So we're not anticipating any impact on utilization of that plant.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Baumgartner with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Baumgartner with Wells Fargo.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kasper, I wanted to clarify, with more imported product coming to China now, so The Netherlands plant, does that, over time, maybe reduce the need for mainland or to go over to Hong Kong back to begin with? So maybe do you derisked the Hong Kong business
componenttext: Kasper, I wanted to clarify, with more imported product coming to China now, so The Netherlands plant, does that, over time, maybe reduce the need for mainland or to go over to Hong Kong back to begin with? So maybe do you derisked the Hong Kong business long-term? And then secondly, just in the U.S. on the powder milk market, I think that since the initial launch, you've been a bit tempered in your outlook for distribution potential after that launch. But it looks like the same store velocity are very strong some incremental distribution gains year-to-date. How are you thinking about distribution of the U.S.? Is that becoming a large market than maybe would've thought 6 months ago?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, John, you're picking up on a good issue. And clearly, by offering a product in China that is identical from the same manufacturing side as the product we are selling in Hong Kong, we are expecting to see a significant amount of cannibalizati
componenttext: Yes. I think, John, you're picking up on a good issue. And clearly, by offering a product in China that is identical from the same manufacturing side as the product we are selling in Hong Kong, we are expecting to see a significant amount of cannibalization between those 2 businesses. However, having said that, we are expecting that this will be a net positive overall business, mainly because servicing the need for imported quality in China solely by the Hong Kong distribution channel limits distribution really to kind of the southern half of China. You might imagine that it's not a very good or effective way to servicing demand in Shanghai or Beijing or even in the West of China. So net-net, we certainly think that this is the right way to go. I also want to stress, I mean, obviously, we didn't have the great foresight to anticipate the disruptions that we are seeing in Hong Kong right now, but I want to sort of stress the risk mitigation element of this initiative as well. You can follow-up with me if I didn't answer that properly. But I want to address your second question as well. I think we continue to be both excited with the potential of the Enfagrow toddler product in the United States, as well as the progress we are making with it. We've seen very significant growth in our distribution of this product as a consequence of the encouraging offtake, really, that the retailers have seen over the past 12 to 24 months. I think most of these distribution gains are probably behind us. And I don't think that we anticipate to see the same number of gains in the 12 months going forward. However, we, as you might imagine, we monitor start of same-store sales very, very closely, and we're very encouraged by what we are seeing on that front as well.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Warren Ackerman from Society Generali.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Warren Ackerman from Society Generali.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First one is on your guidance. You got quite a lot to do to hit the 7% organic growth for the year given the 3% in the first quarter. Just wondering how much of a heavy lifting will be done by the increase in capacity from Holland i
componenttext: A couple of questions. First one is on your guidance. You got quite a lot to do to hit the 7% organic growth for the year given the 3% in the first quarter. Just wondering how much of a heavy lifting will be done by the increase in capacity from Holland into the B2C channel in China versus how much is done by the rest of the business. Just trying to get a feel for the extent of the recovery in Mainland China you expect in H2 to get you near to that 4-year constant dollar guidance. That's the first question. And then secondly, in last year's a lot of stores in the Chinese media talking about the government banning advertising infant formula to encourage breast-feeding, but the government talk about breast-feeding going from 28% to 50% in 5 years time. Just wondering whether you can remind us, Kasper, of your advertising policy in Chinese formula and how bigger headwind might that be for the industry?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. One, thanks for your question. I think it's a very logical one. We feel obviously, we feel good about projection of around 7% constant dollar growth that is contained in our guidance. Really, it's around comparisons. The first quarter, we were lackin
componenttext: Yes. One, thanks for your question. I think it's a very logical one. We feel obviously, we feel good about projection of around 7% constant dollar growth that is contained in our guidance. Really, it's around comparisons. The first quarter, we were lacking very strong performances for some of -- a series of different reasons but in both the United States and in China how we were lapping really strong compare -- comparison basis. I mentioned there were other factors that kind of impacted that in other smaller markets. So the challenge in the first quarter was always going to be very significant for us and I think we came in, as I said, as expected. So it wasn't as a surprise for us that our growth rate was relatively lower in this quarter, and we feel good about our ability to hit our full year projection. Transitioning to the question about this talk about some enhancement or advertising restrictions in China. I think the industry is still trying to understand what exactly the intent and the plan is of this proposed change to the advertising law. It is likely, I think, that it's not going to turn out to be significantly different from either the current situation in China, which prevents advertising to all products that target infants below 6 months of age, or possibly, it may represent a slight expansion to include products for infants of less than 12 months of age, which is sort of consistent with the approach taken in many other Asian markets. Either way, I think we are very familiar with operating in these kinds of frameworks. It allows us to utilize our medical salesforce quite well. And I think we feel well-positioned to continue to compete and drive demand regardless of where this would go. But I know the industry association is in the process of clarifying this with the local authorities.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's tied, as you know, to propose to be tied to some objective to try and increase breast-feeding rates in China. I think we're likely to see some increase in breast-feeding rate, but I think it's going to be more than offset by growth in t
componenttext: Well, I think it's tied, as you know, to propose to be tied to some objective to try and increase breast-feeding rates in China. I think we're likely to see some increase in breast-feeding rate, but I think it's going to be more than offset by growth in the middle class and the movement towards higher-priced products that we are seeing. So we are not projecting any significant change to the trajectory of the market in China based on this.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from Diane Gaster with CLSA.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the margin on the e-commerce business. So I understand the risk mitigation in shipping directly and maybe reducing the amount of alliance on cross-border trade out of Hong Kong and I understand that your pricing product at a premium
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the margin on the e-commerce business. So I understand the risk mitigation in shipping directly and maybe reducing the amount of alliance on cross-border trade out of Hong Kong and I understand that your pricing product at a premium to the locally produced. But I guess I'm just not familiar with whatever discount schedules you have with retailers, brick-and-mortar versus what you can expect on the e-commerce side. So could you talk about expectations? Is there going to be a margin hit from shifting out of Hong Kong into China on that business, imported business? Maybe you could give us a little background there on the distribution channels and discounting, wholesale, et cetera, would be helpful.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we've said before that the most profitable way to play in China is via the model that we've got established through Hong Kong. So that doesn't change. However, we've also said that the margin on both locally produced product in China, and for
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we've said before that the most profitable way to play in China is via the model that we've got established through Hong Kong. So that doesn't change. However, we've also said that the margin on both locally produced product in China, and for that matter, product that is imported and sold at a premium price is very attractive indeed and, in fact, above our global average. We believe that to try and assess any kind of variations in our margins because of cannibalization would really be focusing on the minute stuff and you'd run the risk of losing the bigger picture. I think any improvement in sales and market shares as a consequence of this initiatives in China are likely to drown out any impact on our gross margin. I feel very good about the margin trajectory for the business and I'm not overly concerned, though if you ask me about the precise math, you're right to say that the Hong Kong gross margin is slightly higher than that of the Mainland China business.

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate that and I guess just a follow-on to that, you mentioned that the Hong Kong transaction is pretty limited to Southern China. So can you -- what are you thinking in terms of the increase in distribution across the population base? I mean
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate that and I guess just a follow-on to that, you mentioned that the Hong Kong transaction is pretty limited to Southern China. So can you -- what are you thinking in terms of the increase in distribution across the population base? I mean, how many people is that? Or can you give us some idea about your focus on the emerging middle class? You can now cover x percent than with the importation to be able to cover a y percent. And just in terms of what you think the reachable audience is for your product now that you'll be direct shipping your own?

headline: Mead Johnson Nutrition Company, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, I mean, I'm not sure that we're prepared to give that kind of detailed forecast, Diane, but just conceptually, we, for a variety of reasons, not the least being our history in Southern China, we've always enjoyed a much higher share in the southe
componenttext: Yes, no, I mean, I'm not sure that we're prepared to give that kind of detailed forecast, Diane, but just conceptually, we, for a variety of reasons, not the least being our history in Southern China, we've always enjoyed a much higher share in the southern part of China than we've enjoyed in particularly Eastern and Northern China. Obviously, we are constantly working to address that, as you can imagine, through a number of different initiatives. This is one of them. I also want to say that what we do understand about, particularly Internet channel in China, is that a lot of the growth in the Internet channel is coming from third and fourth year cities in China where the offering of a greater selection of goods is a much bigger advantage than it is in the major cities. So this also becomes a way for us to expand at a relatively low fixed cost into some of those cities where we don't really have feet on the ground.

Yes, Jason, sorry. Sorry for your question, but I'm conscious of time. I think what you are seeing is the impact of foreign exchange running through our revenue line and as it pertains to mixed -- sales mix as well. So obviously, there are more moving parts than simply the change in the commodity costs. 
Feel free to follow up with Kathy. Operator, I think with that, we'll have to close the call. Thank you, everybody, for your participation this morning. And that's concludes our call.
